Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A6_4}Nahlan sits on the floodplain of the Damar River as it cuts through the Jarjara Escarpment. This soil, refreshed yearly by the silt of the flooding river, produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A7}Askar
Settlement.text: {=GChIoZdd}Askar dominates the middle stretches of the Damar River, as it weaves between the bluffs of the Jarjara Escarpment. This region has been thickly populated for thousands of years, but the river is restless, and every few centuries leaps its banks and erases what comes before. This latest regional capital was an imperial encampment during their furthest penetration of the Nahasa several centuries ago, taken over by the Aserai tribes after the legions withdrew.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_A9_2}Wadar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_1}Wadar sits in the rocky wadis at the inland edge of the Jarjara Escarpment, before it gives way to barren gravel plains and dunes. Clouds from the Bahr al-Yeshm drop their last reserves of water here in the spring and winter, giving the land just enough grass to support horse-rearing.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_2}Bait Hatif
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_2}Bait Hatif lies in one of the wadis that are cut through the Jarjara Escarpment by the rare but fierce desert rains. Wells tap the groundwater here and allow subsistence farming, but the wealth of the land comes from the fine horses raised on the grasses that grow on the heights in the spring.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_3}Mabwaz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_3}Mabwaz overlooks the Damar River as it weaves through the mesas of the Jarjara Escarpment. Villagers grow wheat and other crops in the silt of the river floodplain.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A7_4}Zalm
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A7_4}Zalm sits at the Scorched Gates, where the Damar River descends from the Nahasa Desert and starts its journey through the Jarjara Escarpment. The silt brought by the river produces bountiful crops of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_A8}Qasira
Settlement.text: {=J4bgNT0r}The legendary Queen Eshora, it is said, punished the jinn who were harassing her people by imprisoning them in one of the caves above Qasira, carving the mystical eight-pointed star into the rock to seal them in. She sentenced them to haul water from the depths of the earth, feeding the springs that gush forth from the rocks and which for centuries have irrigated the gardens of the Khisba, the small but rich coastal plain that adjoins the city.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_1}Ezbet Nahul lies in the middle of the Khisba, a small but rich coastal plain protected from the deserts by the Jabal Minshar. Villagers tap every source of available freshwater, from cisterns, wells in the ground, or rain-traps in the hills, to devote to the growing of wheat to feed nearby Qasira.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_A8_2}Abghan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_A8_2}Abghan sits by a small lagoon on the southern shores of the Bahr al-Yeshm, the Jade Sea. Villagers here fish for tuna, sardines, bonito and shark.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V1_1}Usanc
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V1_1}Usanc sits on the slopes of the Epiric Hills, overlooking the Gulf of Charas. This warm southern land supports the growing of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V2_1}Hongard
Settlement.text: {=epJhvpdW}Hongard sits in the warm wooded lands near the meandering Trand River. This region, rich in wheat and once the heartland of the Empire, is now the center of the Vlandian kingdom.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V2_2}Ferton
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V2_2}Ferton sits at the base of the Biscan Hills. This warm coast, fragrant with lavender and thyme, is well-suited to the growing of olives..

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V3_1}Drapand
Settlement.text: {=K1XMpxea}Drapand sits near the tip of Cape Fal, a promontory just south of the mouth of the Trand River. The foremost seafaring village on this coast, it gives its name to the bay to its north. The villagers venture out far into the seas to hunt right and blackfish whales, and sometimes range as far north as Beinland chasing bowheads and narwhals.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V4_1}Ormanfard
Settlement.text: {=w6hCZS3K}Ormanfard sits at the foot of the Ormanthal, a pass that leads to the Battanian lands. Rains are plentiful and wheat and barley grow well on the hillsides, but villagers are always alert for the sounds of horns from the castle guarding the pass, warning of Battanian raiders.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V5_1}Tirby
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V5_1}Tirby looks out onto the cold misty waters that lie off of the Ebor peninsula. The low-lying lands on the northern side of the Ebor are suited to the growing of flax.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V5_2}Sirindac
Settlement.text: {=jRaphKwi}Sirindac lies beneath the high ridges of the Ebor peninsula, somewhat sheltered from the bitter winds blowing out of the northwest. It was settled by prospectors hunting for silver in the mountain streams, but that has mostly been exhausted and the region now mostly exports clay for local potters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V6_1}Caleus
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V6_1}Caleus lies on the misty coastal plain south of the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers speak a mix of the Vlandian, Sturgian and Battanian tongues. They grow flax in the lowlands here.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V6_2}Deriat
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V6_2}Deriat sits just inland of the Bay of Drapand. Villagers here raise hogs, herding them to the nearby highlands to forage for nuts and roots.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V7_1}Talivel
Settlement.text: {=shrCpiut}Talivel lies in the middle of the Trand valley in the Vlandian heartland. Villagers plant olives here on the hillsides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V8_1}Verecsand
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_V8_1}Verecsand sits in the lowlands of the Trand valley. Villagers here grow wheat in the gentle downs by the meandering river.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V1}Sargot
Settlement.text: {=aOn6pa0D}Sargot is a common name for hills, promontories, islands and other defensible positions in western Calradia. It refers to a fortified encampment of the Massa, a tribe allied to the the Vlandians who joined their invasion. Though the Massa moved on, their stay was often so traumatic for a district that the name remained long after their departure. This Sargot was actually founded on the ruins of an imperial town, resettled by Vlandians, and which has supplanted the memory of the community that came before it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V1_1}Calioc
Settlement.text: {=TrAqb5E9}Calioc sits in the Neurval, the valley between the Epiric and Biscan Hills. The people of this district grow flax on the wet valley floor.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V1_2}Echarfurd
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V1_2}Echarfurd sits on the northern slopes of the Epiric Hills. Unlike most settlements in the kingdom, it was founded by Vlandian migrants, who named it after a settlement in their old homeland. The villagers here grow wheat, finding a ready market in the garrisons stationed nearby.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V7_2}Rodetan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V1_3}Rodetan takes its name from the ruddy, iron-rich soil of this part of the the Biscan Hills. The mines of this district supply the iron ore for many of the forges of the Vlandian kingdom.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V2}Ocs Hall
Settlement.text: {=nhmBQIC4}Ocs Hall is one of the few towns in the Vlandian kingdom that was founded after the seizure of the land from the Empire. This valley was once an isolated holdout of Battanians, centered on the Llyn Modris, a marshy pool said to be the court of a watery spirit-queen to whom the peoples of the region made offerings. It was conquered however by the Vlandian warlord Oca, who drained the pool for farmland and built his great hall on the heights above. The Battanian tribes were driven inland, over the Rhennod, and took their legends with them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V2_1}Mareiven
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V2_1}Mareiven sits in the Vlandian coastal lowlands, beneath the hills of the Rhennod. Villagers harvest the tall trees of the heights, selling the logs to cities on the coast.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V2_2}Oritan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V2_2}Oritan sits high in the Rhennod, the western escarpment of the Uchalion massif. The families of this region trace their descent to Vlandian mercenaries who intermarried with local hill peoples related to the Battanians.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V2_3}Fregian
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V2_3}Fregian sits in a shallow valley near Ocs Hall. Villagers plant flax on boggy land that was once a marshy lake before it was drained by the Vlandian barons.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V8_2}Marin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V2_4}Marin lies on the edges of the broad valley of the meandering Trand. Misty mornings cooled by sea drifting south and warm afternoons make this land well-suited to the growing of grapes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V3}Pravend
Settlement.text: {=Nx0qK2g6}Paravenos was the second major colony founded by Calradios the Great, and it soon succeeded Charasea as the capital of the Calradians. Eventually, the Empire's center of gravity moved east, but Paravenos retained its primacy as the economic center of the West. When Osric Iron-Arm the Vlandian invaded, he recognized Paravenos would be far more valuable as a seat of power than as simply as a source of loot, and negotiated its surrender with local senators. It passed to a cadet branch of Osric's line, the dey Tihr clan, and is today known as Pravend.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_V3_2}Valanby
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V3_1}Valanby sits overlooking the Trand estuary. The local landowners raise horses in paddocks reclaimed from the riverside marshes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V3_2}Rulund
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V3_2}Rulund sits in the windswept coasts north of the Trand River. Although there are few forests in these parts for the pigs to root, they thrive on the rye and wheat grown on the downs by the sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V3_3}Larnac
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V3_3}Larnac sits on gentle hills on the lower Trand valley. Villagers plant rye, barley and wheat for sale to the hungry urban population of nearby Pravend.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V3_4}Palisont
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V3_4}Palisont sits close to where the Trand River meets the sea. The cool sea air that flows upriver and the warm afternoons allow the growing of wine grapes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_N1}Hvalvik
Settlement.text: {=Zn9NwSTf}Hvalvik is the main port on the remote northern island known to the Nords as Beinland, the land of bones. It is debated whether the island's namesake comes from the walrus ivory that drew hunters here, or the only trace that many left behind, buried in shallow graves alongside its bleak gravel-covered shores. In the last few generations, however, a run of milder winters and a growing mainland population has encouraged colonists to seek their fortune in Beinland, and the former cluster of whalers' huts known as Hvalvik is now a thriving town.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_N2}Gretysfjord
Settlement.text: {=nxmX99pO}Gretysfjord is perhaps the oldest walled town in the Nordvyg, yet there are greybeards here who claim their grandsires were among the first to settle here permanently. At first it was but a seasonal market by the shore, drawing in traders from across the seas, until a local chief built walls and a great hall and began calling himself jarl. It is still the most frequented port on the Nordvyg, a welcome refuge to sailors from the unpredictable and cold northern seas.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_N3}Thronderlag
Settlement.text: {=Lg5rbZse}Thronderlag was the gathering place of the Throndar, the legendary progenitors of the Nordic realm. Here, overlooking the sea, the clans would assemble on the cold spring equinox to resolve their disputes, choose a target for summertime raiding, and elect a warleader. Today the Nord king takes counsel mainly with a select group of his jarls in his hall, and such great assemblies are no longer held, but Thonderlag remains the symbolic center of the Nordvyg.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_N4}Hargard
Settlement.text: {=zh2tG1MX}Nordic tribes pushing into the dark forests to their east founded the citadel of Hargard several generations ago. It overlooks the river that the Nords call the Jumne, probably a derivation of a Sturgian term for the mysterious burial pits found along its banks. Today, the river forms the main artery of transportation for the Nord kingdom's eastern domains, a meeting-place of Nords, Vakken, Sturgians, and even some forest-dwelling cousins of the steppe tribes, all harvesting the wealth of the river-valley to sell to the peoples of the south.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N1_1}Laxahof
Settlement.text: {=yOezgAaK}Laxahof sits on a low promontory that juts into the Byalic Sea, on the war-torn marches that divide the Sturgian and Nordic lands. In past generations its inhabitants made their living by signing on to dangerous, freezing whaling ventures organized by Byalic Sea merchants. Rrecently they have begun to organize their own voyages, bringing home wealth to what was once one of the poorest corners of the north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N1_2}Agilting
Settlement.text: {=j84R3OFX}The village of Agilting on the eastern shores of the Byalic Sea began as a gathering point for local fishers and herders to resolve their claims and feuds. Like many such sites in the north, it has evolved into a village as local populations grew.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N2_1}Kjarved
Settlement.text: {=dVSR4l4D}Kjarved lies in the inland valleys of the western Nordvyg. Villagers tell stories of their famously foul-tempered and miserly ancestor Kjar, who came inland from the sea to escape a blood feud. For 60 years he mined salt from nearby deposits and accumulated a fabulous trove of wealth, all of which was a huge surprise to his dozens of children and grandchildren when they entered his modest farmhouse after his death to claim their inheritance.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N2_2}Tharklif
Settlement.text: {=azr733J3}The seafaring village of Tharklif lies at the foot of a cliff overlooking the Byalic Sea. The inhabitants fish local stocks of char and cod, but are most known for their long-ranging voyages in pursuit of right whales and bowheads which migrate through these waters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N3_1}Ykerslund
Settlement.text: {=mSaQ0Cof}Ykerslund is one of the northernmost districts of the Nordic kingdom. Its first inhabitants settled around a grove sacred to a wilderness goddess, and every year sacrifice in the hope of receiving her blessing to hunt in nearby woods.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N3_2}Hoeksten
Settlement.text: {=hBOy8ZUM}Hoeksten is named after a mysterious monolith found in the fields here by wandering herdsmen, subsequently ordered dug up by the local jarl and used in the foundations of Ykerslund Castle. He also ordered a village built on the auspicious site to settle refugees who had fled from the wars of Nord unification on the coast, and provided them with herds of cattle.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N4_1}Ruvenbrek
Settlement.text: {=LkKDVSJa}Ruvenbrek sits in the far northeast of the lands settled by the Nords. Rich deposits of iron ore in the soil here, their wealth visible from rust-brown streaks on hillsides or in the waters of bogs, have drawn migrants to this otherwise remote and forbidding region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N4_2}Svinstak
Settlement.text: {=h5tD3Cjj}Svinstak lies inland of the Nordvyg coast, separated from the sea by a row of sharp-ridged hills. Stands of old-growth oak and other trees are still common here, providing the north with much of the timber for its ships.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N5_1}Fimbulgard
Settlement.text: {=EaH59vf8}Fimbulgard was named for the beach-side shacks used to dry herring, the staple food of its seafaring inhabitants. The wealth of the village, however, comes from the seasonal voyages along the northern coasts in search of whales and their oil.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N5_2}Draugmyr
Settlement.text: {=Y5YbDNKp}The village of Draugmyr takes its name from a nearby bog that was once a place of sacrifice. Though long since drained to create farmland, its rich wheatfields still turn up the odd bone or golden grave-offering.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N6_1}Haugr
Settlement.text: {=TKeLjx14}Haugr sits on the eastern branch of the Jumne River, where it meanders over its floodplain. It was named after a stone cairn on a riverside bluff, said by locals to have been built by trolls from the nearby tundra. The region produces fine, dark clays, much prized by local potters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N6_2}Nifdal
Settlement.text: {=8rKzYF3g}Nifdal is named for the dense mists that rise in the morning from the nearby Jumne river. The villagers here raise shaggy-haired cattle bred to withstand the bitter winters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N7_1}Hakarshus
Settlement.text: {=2pt8EBsS}Hakarshus was the first settlement on the northern coast of Beinland. Its founder, Hakar, harbored a resentment towards authority that was fierce even by local standards. His descendants have become walrus hunters and whalers, venturing to the far north, away from kings and jarls and taxes, in search of their quarry.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N7_2}Bjorenbyr
Settlement.text: {=yowxgqGD}The village of Bjorenbyr on the downs of western Beinland was founded only two generations ago, as the people of Beinland began to settle inland. It harvests the old-growth forests of the highlands, where great trees might still be found, and are much valued by shipbuilders on the coast and the mainland.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N8_1}Skarthness
Settlement.text: {=4L56zPos}The clifftop village of Skarthness is known for its intrepid mariners. While most of their neighbors are content to fish nearby banks, Skarthnessers voyage seasonally to the far north of Beinland on walrus hunts, bringing back valuable ivory.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N8_2}Troverag
Settlement.text: {=ozyk0Toa}Troverag is a mining colony in the bleak hills overlooking the Byalic Sea. The dour inhabitants are known for laboring long into the night, and the glow of their forges can be seen far from shore.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N9_1}Ulikshorn
Settlement.text: {=0kDUOy2G}Ulikshorn lies beside the Jumne River as it cuts through the hills known as the Iltanhindrun, named because they posed a barrier to mountain tribes just across the frontiers. Those peoples were pushed farther south and absorbed into the Khuzait confederacy, leaving a considerable land trafficked only by nomadic herdsmen and raiders. The region is rich in wheat, barley and other grains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_N9_2}Thralathorp
Settlement.text: {=DJCei132}Thralathorp was settled by fugitives and runaways from various estates in the Jumne valley. It lies far to the east of the main Nord settlements, on the edge of the steppe. Isolation, freezing winters and frequent Khuzait raids ensure that there are few who would bother disputing their title. The people here make what money they can scraping clay from the bottom of the river in the months when the land is not frozen solid.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N1_1}Aalgrun
Settlement.text: {=vTBy6iqW}The fishing village of Aalgrun is known for the eels that thrive in the offshore shallows. Slightly further out to sea fishermen also find herring, as well as char that migrates to the sea from nearby streams to spawn.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N1_2}Lagshofn
Settlement.text: {=OBPnMiGG}The village of Lagshofn was founded by the explorer and trade Lag, who cast his seat-pillars into the sea and followed them to this spot. His intrepid descendants sail from here into the straits between Hvalvik and Vlandia, where they hunt right whales, blackfish and other quarry on their migration routes between the Byalic Sea and the northern ocean.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N1_3}Ravikayr
Settlement.text: {=INqm4EHB}Ravikayr sits on rich volcanic soil in the interior of Beinland. Here, on the lower slopes of the dark Oskfjal mountain, much of the island's supply of grain is grown.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N1_4}Gripsby
Settlement.text: {=UEIJSj9y}Gripsby, on the east coast of Beinland, was founded early in the island's settlement by mainlanders who hunted walrus on nearby beaches. These days they must venture farther afield, to the north of Beinland and the frozen seas beyond, but they still take a rich haul of valuable ivory.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N2_1}Dagby
Settlement.text: {=HvHbfLWH}Dagby lies in the heights above Gretysfjord. Residents of the town harvest the great oaks on the slopes for the town's shipbuilding industry. On the summer solstice, village youths race by riding the logs as they slide down the hill, risking mangled limbs or broken backs for a chance at glory.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N2_2}Midskag
Settlement.text: {=rKW7FqWa}Midskag is named after the cape that lies roughly halfway from the western end of the Nordvyg to the capital of Thronderlag. The villagers of the region near Midskag make their living from the sea, harvesting cod and ice-char from nearby banks.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N2_3}Dorstrand
Settlement.text: {=AG9UT2dx}Dorstrand overlooks a grim gravel beach in the western end of the Nordvyg. Villagers earn their living by fishing cod, char and other arctic fish, including a variety of deepwater sharks whose flesh must be fermented before it is eaten.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N2_4}Mjallagdal
Settlement.text: {=KtN9VSiR}Mjallagdal sits in a thickly wooded valley inland from Gretysfjord. Trees in these woods are often marked with the glyph of an horned archer carved into the bark, the work of a villager invoking the help of the god Ulthin in their hunt for marten, squirrel and other fur-bearing animals.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N3_1}Jalskveg
Settlement.text: {=JJ0fLBlD}Jalskveg, in the east of the Nordvyg north of Thronderlag, lies on one of the main routes from the coast to the more sparsely populated interior. The area is thick with ancient oak trees, which are harvested and dragged to the coast by oxen for use in shipbuilding.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N3_2}Ostrif
Settlement.text: {=4aWgJfSi}Ostrif sits on a plateau on the eastern end of the Nordvyg coast. The villagers raise cattle on the grassy pastures above the sea-cliffs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N3_3}Holarsver
Settlement.text: {=AvIb3tGu}The villagers of Holarsver fish the eastern Byalic Sea, where the runoff from the streams creates a brackish mix of saltwater and fresh. Here the catch consists of salmon, sea-trout and bottom-dwelling fish like flounder, caught in wicker traps.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N3_4}Vagnafit
Settlement.text: {=fVkcvgSc}Vagnafit lies in a basin under the hills known as the Kjolfjallen, from their resemblance to the keel of a ship. The once boggy depression was drained under the orders of King Volbjorn, and the land distributed to some of the veterans who helped him gain power to grow wheat for Thronderlag and other towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N4_1}Grudhammar
Settlement.text: {=dwkbyCqk}Grud was a thegn of the jarl of Hargard who established an outpost east of the Jumne River, which takes its name from the mysterious burial pits from some bygone people that lined its banks. The village named after him now herds sheep that range far out over the cold steppe to the east.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N4_2}Vorfjall
Settlement.text: {=Q3lvcUub}Vorfjall lies on the hills east of the Jumne, known for the bloom of purple lupin that fill the highland meadows in the late spring. The village sustains itself mining salt from deposits, some in vibrant streaks of color, that can be found in the nearby hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N4_2}Faergap
Settlement.text: {=PKlv8jCB}Faergap lies on the passage through the bleak hills that divide the eastern coasts of the Byalic Sea from the Jumne valley. As the pass crests, and the rich lands of the Jumne come into view, a traveller can read runic inscriptions carved on boulders by Nordic migrants, giving thanks to the gods for their safe journey.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_N4_4}Gauksdal
Settlement.text: {=4fLQlZya}Gauksdal sits on the middle reaches of the Jumne, the river that the Khuzaits call the Karakaz. This stretch of valley is named in commemoration of Gauk, a local homesteader, who escaped a Khuzait ambush by swimming across the river in spring when it was choked with floating ice. Villagers now plant flax by the river's weedy shallows.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V5}Galend
Settlement.text: {=UCrwAaba}Galend overlooks the wave-beaten Biscan coast. It takes in the catch from the Biscan's intrepid fishermen and whalers who venture out far into the western ocean, as well as the wool of sheep from the green fog-covered hills. The current line of Vlandian kings comes from the clans who settled in this region during Osric Iron-Arm's invasion.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V5_1}Furbec
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V5_1}Furbec sits on a shelf overlooking the rocky Biscan coast of central Vlandia. The climate is warm most of the year, and grapes do well on the slopes of the Biscan Hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V5_2}Meroc
Settlement.text: {=ameOg5g7}Meroc overlooks a cove in the Biscan Coast. Like many villages in this region, its inhabitants fish nearby banks for mullet and cod for their day-to-day meals, while its bolder seafarers go much further into the western ocean to hunt more lucrative quarry, in particular whales.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V5_3}Nogrent
Settlement.text: {=UIrbLGBx}The village of Nogrent sits high on a ridge overlooking the Biscan coast. Grapes grown here are pressed to make a sturdy wine, a key ingredient in the hearty fishermen's soups for which the Biscan region is famous.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V6}Jaculan
Settlement.text: {=R6YJsK89}Jaculan sits in the warmer southern reaches of the Biscan coast, in rolling hills known for their olive trees. It was once a favored resort of the imperial aristocracy, who hunted wild boars amid the oak forests. The independent peasantry of this region are known for their heterodox ideas. The Brotherhood of the Woods is but the latest of a series of rebellions to have broken out here, sometimes aided by an aristocracy that considers them a tool to use against rival Vlandian houses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V6_1}Arromanc
Settlement.text: {=ptaZeOkf}Arromanc lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills. The warm lands of the Vlandian south, where the air smells of sage, lavender and thyme, are well-suited to the growing of olives.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V6_2}Mot
Settlement.text: {=OAK0kjBo}Mot lies in the Neurval, a valley that runs between the Biscan and Epiric hills, known for the blaze of poppies that cover its slopes in the spring. The warm lands of the Vlandian south are well-suited to the growing of olives.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V6_3}Alorstan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V6_3}Alorstan sits on a shelf overlooking the sea, at the foot of the Biscan Hills. The warm south of the Vlandian lands is well-suited to the cultivation of olives.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V6_4}Chornad
Settlement.text: {=1ZMvRYTm}Chornad in the Neurval Valley, beneath the Biscan Hills. The villagers of this region, like many in the central Vlandian kingdom, specializing in raising pigs on the plentiful acorns that fall from the region's oak trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V7}Charas
Settlement.text: {=0cZmKO76}The city known today as Charas is traditionally reckoned to be the first Calradian colony on the shores of their new continent. At the Empire's height, when the capital moved north to Paravenos, Charasea remained a key hub of sea-faring and trade, while imperial aristocrats built their summer homes on the warm shores of the nearby gulf and cruised their pleasure-boats around its islands. When the Vlandians came, Charas fell into the hands of the ruthless House of dey Cortain, and its wealth funds their ambitions.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V7_1}Savinth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V7_1}Savinth sits on a wooded hillside north of the Gulf of Charas. Just down the slope lies fine pasture for the renowned horses of the Vlandians.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V7_2}Vesin
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V7_2}The village of Vesin lies by a creek running down from the Epiric Hills to the Gulf of Charas. This warm land is well-suited to the growing of olive trees.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V8}Ostican
Settlement.text: {=Eb7Lgq10}Ostican was a minor imperial port that became a haven for seafarers of the northern oceans. Many were talented corsairs, employed by imperial factions to harry their foes during the latter empire's intermittent civil wars. Indeed, the some of the first Vlandians to come to Calradia's shores settled in the back alleys of this town, and no doubt sent word to their kinsmen of the riches to be had here should anyone invade in earnest.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V8_1}Horsger
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V8_1}Horsger is where, according to legend, the warrior Horsa came ashore and planted his spear in the beach. Today it is known for its horses, who graze in rocky coastal slopes flecked with primrose and daffodils.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V8_2}Cananc
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V8_2}Cananc lies in the wet wooded hills of the Ebor Peninsula, where yew trees grow tall in the sea-mists. The village is known for producing fine pigs, who are allowed to range through the thick woods rooting for acorns, chestnuts and grubs. Towering fir and spruce grow on the slopes. This rule of of the Vlandian barons in this rugged land is much lighter than in the south, attracting many migrants who value the relative freedom.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V8_3}Remental
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V8_3}Remental sits on a ledge of the Ebor Peninsula, overlooking the sea. Vlandian settlers originally here came to mine silver, but those ores were quickly exhausted. Desperate prospectors were able to locate some deposits of salt, which was much in demand as the coasts here are generally too steep for the creation of salt pans.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_V9}Rovalt
Settlement.text: {=1SnAH5K8}Rovalatys, in the mountains of the Ebor Peninsula, was never fully an imperial town. Nordic migrants, drawn to the region by rumors of riches to be made prospecting for silver or hunting for furs, long outnumbered Calradians even before the Vlandian invasion. The Vlandians too recognized its potential, and despite its harsh winters this land is among the more populous regions of the kingdom, with bountiful fields in the valleys of the mountains feeding the constant flow of settlers from the south drawn here by their hunger for wealth.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V9_1}Alantas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V9_1}Alantas sits in the center of the mountainous Ebor Peninsula. The soil here is thin and the weather here is cold, but rich iron deposits sustain the local economy.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_V9_2}Halisvust
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_V9_2}Halisvust was once a bog amid the scrubby coastal woods at the base of the Ebor Peninsula, but Vlandian settlers drained the waters and sowed wheat and rye.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B1_1}Ab Comer sits on the Etircomb, the steep valley which climbs from the Vlandian coastal plain to the Uchalion plateau, cut by the small creeks feeding the Trand River. The tribes of this region grow grapes on the hillsides, used to make a white wine popular with the imperial and Vlandian aristocracies.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B2_1}Llanoc Hen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B2_1}Llanoc Hen sits at the foot of the Cafalcombe that climbs from the western imperial lands to the Uchalion massif. Oak and other trees grow thick in the valley, providing nuts and thick roots to feed the local hogs.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B2_2}Cantrec
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B2_2}Cantrec sits in the rocky Cafalcombe that climbs up from the imperial lands into the plateau of the Uchalion. The lands is not especially fertile here, but pigs thrive in the bush and shrubland of the heights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B3_1}Druimmor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B3_1}Druimmor sits at one of the highest points on the Uchalion massif, the mountain fastness at the heart of the Battanian realm. Miners here have found silver in clefts in the hillsides.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B4_1}Pendraic
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B4_1}Pendraic sits on a high outcrop beneath the lofty Ben Callach, said to have been a stone dropped by the divine crone Callach as she swept over the Uchalion bringing winter storms from the north. To the west it overlooks the Llyn Tywal lake, and to its south a steep pass that is traditionally one of the main routes between the Battanian heartland on the Uchalion massif and the Empire. The villagers raise hogs here on acorns which grow from oak trees on the heights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B5_1}Rhemtoil
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B5_1}Rhemtoil lies beneath a cleft in the eastern escarpment of the Uchalion plateau. A waterfall cascades down the cliffside here to form River Miron, which the Battanians call the Myr. This is among the most fertile of the Battanian lands, and produces a fine crop of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B5_2}Claig Ban
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B5_2}Claig Ban sits nestled in a small hollow amid the heights of the Uchalion massif. The clays of this region are much prized for their vivid red hues.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B6_1}Flintolg
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B6_1}Flintolg sits on the so-called Stairs of Morac, a series of trails that run up the more accessible slopes of the Ailta Druin escarpment. The soil is poor but the woods grow thick here, making this the source of much of the timber used in the Battanian lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B6_2}Glintor
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B6_2}Glintor sits on a bluff towards the bottom of the Ailtra Druin cliffs, looking down upon the sea that the Battanians call the Muir Gal. Horses are raised on patches of rich pastureland in the glens between the crags, much prized by both raiders and traders from the Sturgian across the water.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B7_1}Aster
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B7_1}Aster perches amid the crags of the Ailtra Druin, between the heights of the Uchalion and the sea. The people of this region have the reputation of being more focused on trade than warfare, and tribal elders have encouraged the planting of vineyards to produce a particularly strong vintage of wine.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B8_1}Uthelaim
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_B8_1}Uthelaim sits on the eastern frontiers of the Battanian lands on a ridge overlooking a tributary of the Myr, just before it rushes down the slope towards Lake Laconis, and the Empire. The people of these parts are foresters, felling the oak, yew and pine of the woods for sale to builders and shipwrights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B1}Marunath
Settlement.text: {=Jm2uZiwV}Marunath, the 'Horse of the Ford,' is nowhere near a river. But Battanian bards love nothing more than an incongruous place-name around which a legend can be woven. In this case the hero Ochlaigan, who was foretold to defeat the seven sons of Glanys in seven duels near seven fords, encountered the last of his enemies here. He slit his horse's throat and crossed over the stream of blood that gushed forth, defeating his last enemy and fulfiling the prophecy.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_1}Dalmengus
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_1}Dalmengus sits by the side of the Llyn Tywal, the dark lake at the center of the Uchalion massif. The flat, well-watered lands here are fertile and well-suited to wheat and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_2}Ebereth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_2}Ebereth is one of several villages on the densely populated southern shores of the Llyn Tywal, the dark lake at the heart of the Battanian lands. The people here here grow grapes to make the sweet white wine of the Battanian lands.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_3}Beglomuar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_3}Beglomuar sits at the crest of the Cafalcombe. The soil is thin and rocky, and there is little to recommend these lands other than the ore deposits in the hills and the bog-iron of the mountain marshes.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B1_4}Ath Cafal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B1_4}Ath Cafal sits near the head of the Cafalcombe, a steep valley that descends to the imperial lands. The villagers gather fine clay from local streambeds to trade to the potters of nearby towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B2}Dunglanys
Settlement.text: {=YERtiSUn}Dunglanys, the 'Rock of Glanys', stands on a high crag overlooking the Llyn Tywal, the pool of darkness at the heart of the Battanian lands. It was named after a ancient queen who, legend has it, married in succession five high kings of Battania, bestowing sovereignty upon them. It is the center of the rituals that underpin Battanian kingship, and though not every Battanian high king has ruled from here, all are eager to hold it.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B2_1}Diantogmail
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_1}Diantogmail lies in winding valleys in hill country to the east of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. There are a half-dozen local legends explaining how the region got its name, which means the 'Flight of the Stoat,' but no two of them match in any particulars. Villagers here gather clay from the lakeside for use by nearby artisans.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B2_2}Glenlithrig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_2}Glenlithrig, the valley of the slippery stream, lies in the highlands of the northern Uchalion. The villagers here are primarily foresters, supplying timber to the nearby fortress-towns of Dunglanys and Car Banseth.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B2_3}Morihig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_3}Morihig lies in the Morcomb, a valley on the western side of the Uchalion massif. The region is known for its production of wheat and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B7_2}Imlagh
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_4}Imlagh lies below the heights of the Ailta Druin, overlooking the Muir Gal sea. The village specializes in white grapes for the making of the sweet Battanian wines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B4_2}Lindorn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B2_5}Lindorn sits on the green hills north and west of Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The surrounding farmlands are sown with wheat and barley.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B3}Car Banseth
Settlement.text: {=QD3oaaNK}Car Banseth sits on the bay that the Battanians used to call Muir Mon. The seafaring clans of this coast claim that the ancestors of the Battanians came across these waters to settle their lands. They say that those who keep faith will one day witness from this high point the ships of the vanished High King Mon, who shall return to deliver his people from their enemies. But today, they call it the Muir Gal, the foreigner's sea, as one is far more likely to see the sails of Nordic adventurers and mercenaries, coming to join Sturgians, Vlandians and others in their relentless push into Battanian land.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B3_1}Bog Beth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_1}Bog Beth sits in a forested glen at the seaward side of Ben Callach mountain. Villagers trap beavers, foxes and other fur-bearing animals in the dark, marshy woods.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B3_2}Geunat Nal
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_2}Geunat Nal, the village where Nal left his head, is a fur-trapping village near the site of a duel famous in Battanian legend. The villagers are known for their skill as foresters, helping the nearby sea-fort of Car Banseth to guard the northern approaches to the Battanian heartland from Sturgian and other raiders.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B3_3}Tor Leiad
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B3_3}Tor Leiad, the hill of the full moon, lies beneath a wooded knoll in a small patch of Battanian lowland near Car Banseth. Villagers harvest the thick-growing forests of oak, yew and beech that grow on the heights above their homes. The woods here have been tended carefully by the Battanians for centuries, ensuring that there are always enough trees to harvest and sell for timber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B3_2}Tor Melina
Settlement.text: {=23fxNyp4}Tor Melina lies on a flank of the Morcomb, a valley at the northwestern edge of the Battanian realm. The slopes, well-drained and exposed to the sun, produce a fine crop of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B4}Seonon
Settlement.text: {=X3MsaG39}Seonon, sad Seonon, has a history as dark as the waters of the Llyn Tywal. Here Algana the Fair stood atop the tower lamenting the death of her beloved Gorawan, until the spirits of the Otherworld were themselves overcome with sadness and allowed his shade to ascend through the pool for a day and a night to console her. In latter days this land has often been ravaged by Sturgian raiders, and not far from here lies the wood where King Aeril disappeared, clearing the way for the rise of Caladog.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_1}Bryn Glas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_1}Bryn Glas sits on the eastern shores of the Llyn Tywal. Villagers raise grapes on the slopes, making a strong, dark red wine highly valued by the Vlandians and the Empire.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_2}Andurn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_2}Andurn sits on a grassy down overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. The villagers of these parts tend the forests, harvesting beech, oak and yew for sale to the towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_3}Mag Arba
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_3}Mag Arba sits on grassy downs overlooking Llyn Tywal, the dark lake. Villagers have planted flax in the boggy dales between the hills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B4_4}Swenryn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_4}Swenryn gives its name to the waterfall that cascades down the cliffs at the eastern edge of the Uchalion. Horses graze in lush pastures fed by the mists.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B8_2}Seordas
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B4_5}Seordas sits in the lowlands at the eastern edge of the Battanian lands, at the foot of the Uchalion's cliffs. The land is watered by the tributaries of the Myr River and the soil is rich, but in wartime there are few natural protections against the maraudings of Sturgian and imperial raiders.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_B5}Pen Cannoc
Settlement.text: {=4OAz8urz}Pen Cannoc sits on a promontory overlooking the Etircomb pass as it plunges from the Uchalion plateau into the Vlandian lowlands. Legends speak of the water-nymphs who live in springs that form in the cliffside, luring travellers and invaders to their deaths, except on those rare occasions when they fall in love with a hero and grant him victory and blessings. Certainly the people of this region have learned respect for the perils of the Etircomb, where a small misstep on slippery stone can cast one off a precipice into the gorge below.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B5_1}Durn
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_1}Durn sits just below the crags that form the crest of the Etircomb, the steep valley that climbs from the Vlandian coastal lowlands to the Uchalion massif. Villagers scrape mud from mountain creekbeds, carting it up the winding paths to the town of Pen Cannoc perched on the cliff above them.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B5_2}Gainseth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_2}Gainseth sits in dense woods that grow near the stronghold of Pen Cannoc. Villagers collect mud from the marshy ground for sale to the potters of Pen Cannoc.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_B5_3}Fenon Etir
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_3}Fenon Etir lies in the Etircomb, the steep valley that leads from the Vlandian coastal lowlands to the Uchalion massif. The trails to the village pass by mounds of slag, the detritus from centuries of mining the iron-rich ores of the nearby hills, exposed by the creeks that run down from the heights.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_B1_2}Inveth
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_B5_4}Inveth sits where the River Etir forms from streams that tumble down the Uchalion massif before reaching the coastal lowlands, where they feed into the Trand. The surrounding hillsides support the growing of wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K1_1}Usek
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K1_1}Usek sits atop an escarpment of the Akkan Hills on the eastern shores of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers, who until recently were nomads, raise sheep known for the long, fine wool.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K1_2}Esme
Settlement.text: {=f7tdonHz}The village of Esme and its surrounding hamlets lie on the landward side of the Akkan Hills on the Devseg plateau, prime grazing lands for the horses of the Khuzaits and their confederates.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K2_1}Akiser
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K2_1}Akiser sits in the southern reaches of the Akkan Hills. The land here is exceptionally broken and weathered, revealing seams of iron in the sides of the gullies and ravines.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K3_1}Hakkun
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K3_1}The village of Hakkun sits beneath the escarpment of the Akkan Hills. The people of these parts have long mined silver from the mountains, a trade that the Khuzait khans were happy to encourage when they conquered this region.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K4_1}Tepes
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K4_1}Tepes sits in forested lowlands between the Devseg plateau and the lake that the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. This district specializes in the harvest of timber, which is dragged by oxen to the water and then floated to the lake towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K5_1}Khimli
Settlement.text: {=pk7L6pkL}Khimli sits in a basin in the Devseg plateau. Though this land is dry most of the year, it experiences winter snowfalls and muddy springs. Fine clay can be collected from the pools left by the snowmelt and the rains.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K6_1}Dinar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K6_1}Dinar lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, along the Karakaz River. Here, tribes recently arrived from the steppe have intermarried with refugees pushed south from the Jumne valley by recent Nord expansion. The villagers herd sheep out on the open grassland of the steppe.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K6_2}Karahalli
Settlement.text: {=VbQhrOU9}Karahalli lies in the far north of the Khuzait confederacy, in borderlands contested by Sturgians and Nords. Though the winters are cold, the spring grasses are fine grazing for the local sheep, whose thick wool protects them from the region's piercing winds.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K7_1}Simira
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K7_1}The villagers of Simira raise cattle by the grassy shores of the Tiagys River, known to the Khuzaits as the Teyagh. The river here still runs fast after its descent from the hills, and in springtime the villagers have learned to watch closely for signs of a flood that will force them to get their herds to higher ground.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K8_1}Erzenur
Settlement.text: {=6ygg4wPV}Erzenur sits alongside the east branch of the Tiagys River. It is known in the local dialect as the Kizil Teyagh from the strong reddish tint in the iron-rich sediments borne in its currents. Villagers will often divert the waters to wash away soil and expose new seams of ore.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K9_1}Kaysar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K9_1}Kaysar sits in the north and east of the lands ruled by the Khuzaits, in the valley of the Karakaz River. This district is snowbound for much of the year, but villagers still raise herds of cattle bred to withstand the icy winds coming downriver from the north.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K9_2}Payam
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.castle_village_K9_2}Payam lies alongside the Davana River in the cold north of the Khuzait lands, not far from where it joins with the Karakaz and runs down to the sea. Though the land is snowbound much of the year, the villagers sow wheat and barley as soon as the melt starts, taking in a good crop before the autumn.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_K1}Baltakhand
Settlement.text: {=YNm9vaHw}Baltakhand, the Fortress of the Axe, was settled by the Iltanlar, mountain-dwelling cousins of the Khuzaits. Centuries ago their beys descended into the plains and created the fortress here that guards the portages of Iltan, the network of lakes and rivers that divides the Sturgian lands from the Khuzaits' realm. Bitter winters protected them from the reach of the Empire, but no blast of wind was cutting enough to stop the horsemen of Khan Urkhun, who 40 years ago forced this town to submit to the khanate.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K1_1}Fisnar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K1_1}Fisnar sits in the grasslands east of the Karakaz River. Snow-bound for much of the year, the spring grasses nonetheless sustain sizeable herds of sheep, the thick wool of which protects them from the bitter winter cold.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K1_2}Ulaan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K1_2}Ulaan sits where the land gently rises from the valley of the Karakaz River to the slopes of the Sulan Dag. The villagers, nomads who have recently been forced by the khans to settle, have learned to grow flax for their livelihoods.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K4_2}Kuruluk
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K1_3}Kuruluk sits in the shadow of the peak known as Bars Dag. Though this valley is snowbound for much of the year, steppe ponies thrive on the spring grasses and in the winter dig through the snow for food, their thick coats protecting them from the icy blasts of wind. Villagers keep watch to protect them from the leopards for which the mountain is named.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K1_4}Asalig
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K1_4}Asalig sits at the foot of the Sulan Dag mountains, dividing the northern Khuzait lands from the sparsely populated steppe to the east. Villagers raise horses in the lower slopes, keeping watch for the leopards that descend from the high peaks in the winter, when the game is scarce.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_K2}Akkalat
Settlement.text: {=4UNOQQRa}The town that the Khuzaits know as Akkalat, the White Fortress, was built by the fearsome Padishah Hoshtar on one of his periodic attempts to conquer the Devseg. For decades the sacred flame that burned from the top of the citadel symbolized his suzerainty over the tribes here. But the Padishah's realm like the Empire is on the defensive and has retreated to the east. Today the Khan's horsetail banners fly in its place.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K2_1}Karakalat
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K2_1}Karakalat lies at the southern end of the Akkan Hills. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and it is still famous as a breeding ground for horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K2_2}Kohi Ajik
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K6_4}Kohi Ajik lies in a valley at the foot of the so-called Lover's Mountain, from which its name derives. To its east spring the headwaters of the Ozu River, one of the sources of the mighty Tiagys.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K8_2}Gereden
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K2_3}Gereden lies amid the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn, near the headwaters of the Kizil Tayegh River. The clay from this region, known for its reddish tint, is highly valued by the artisans of Odokh and other nearby towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K3_2}Kiraz
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K2_4}Kiraz lies in a basin at the southern end of the Devseg plateau. Until recently, this land was dominated by nomads, and the people here still make their living by raising sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_K3}Makeb
Settlement.text: {=bPDqyqkb}Makeb sits on the northern tip of Lake Tanaesis, Tanaz in the steppe tongue. This city has long been ruled by petty khans and shahs, who collect tolls from traders forced to haul their boats around the rapids. The last of those rulers was beheaded by Urkhun himself after he refused a demand of tribute, after which the ruling family of the Khuzaits seized this town for themselves.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K3_1}Shapeshte
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K3_1}The fishing village of Shapeshte sits on a bay in Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. Carp and catfish were introduced to the gentle murky waters of the lakeshore back when these lands were controlled by the Empire, and today make up the majority of the fishermen's catch.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K3_2}Hanekhy
Settlement.text: {=2IZ3PZWZ}Hanekhy sits atop a northern spur of the Akkan Hills. Each day, the villagers climb down winding paths to tend their wheatfields in the plains below.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K3_3}Mazen
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K3_3}The village of Mazen sits on the northern end of Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The northern winters here are tempered by the lake, and the villagers raise mulberry trees here to feed silkworms.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_K4}Ortongard
Settlement.text: {=jlLJSudl}Ortongard sits near the eastern edges of the Devseg plateau. The land is dry for most of the year but offers rich grazing in the spring. Founded by Darshi-speaking merchants, it made its wealth buying horses, sheep and cattle from the surrounding herding villages and sending them west to the markets of the Empire in huge drives, accompanied by guards to ward off raiders from the steppes. Neither its walls nor its mercenary armies could withstand the coming of Khan Urkhun, however, who granted it to the Khergit clan in recognition of their valor.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K5_2}Omrotok
Settlement.text: {=udB5YibE}Omrotok sits at the foot of the Sulun Dag mountains, which mark the eastern border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers go to the nearby woods to harvest one of the Devseg's few sources of timber.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K4_2}Ransam
Settlement.text: {=giPDsrGr}Ransam lies in the southern plains of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, specialize in the rearing of horses.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K4_3}Mivanjan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K4_3}Mivanjan sits near an escarpment of the Akkan Hills, which marks the western border of the Devseg plateau. Villagers, who not long ago still lived a nomadic lifestyle, raise sheep in the foothills.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K4_4}Urunjan
Settlement.text: {=eutVVgbR}Urunjan sits near the eastern edge of the Devseg plateau, at the foot of the Sulan Dag mountains. Villagers raise cattle here that are bred to withstand both the hot summers and freezing winters.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_K5}Chaikand
Settlement.text: {=SUnaVliN}Chaikand sits by the reed-marshes on the edge of Lake Tanaesis. In the years when the east was an imperial protectorate, boats laden with hides, wool and salt shuttled across the lake's placid waters, returning with imperial silks and silver. With the coming of the Khuzaits and the subsequent wars the water-trade stopped, but Chaikand remains a major trade entrepot and military base, the fief of the ruling Urkhunait clan. From the pavilions of his palace, the khan can look out across the lake and see the hazy outline of hills that he may one day graze his horses upon.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K2_2}Kamshar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_1}Kamshar sits beneath a low range of hills separating Lake Tanaesis from the western tributaries of the Tayegh River. by Villagers collect clay from the riverbed for sale to the potters of Chaikand and other towns.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K5_2}Okhutan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_2}Okhutan is a village at the center of a wheat-growing district on a narrow stretch of plain between the Akkan Hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K5_3}Ispantar
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_3}Ispantar is a village on a rocky spur of the Akkan Hills overlooking Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. The villagers here make most of their income from the raising of sheep.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K5_4}Pabastan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K5_4}Pabastan sits in the narrow plain between the Akkan Hills and Lake Tanaesis, which the Khuzaits call the Tanaz Sea. This land is fine country for wheat.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.town_K6}Odokh
Settlement.text: {=ygJkPxyc}The town of Odokh sits at the foot of Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. Among the most remote of the towns of the Devseg, it is reputed to have been the abode of King Ahhak, a mythical tyrant from whose shoulders flowed serpents. Even today the Kohi Rohini has a reputation for black magic and mystery that helps keep outsiders at bay. The city fell during the Khuzait conquest to the Harfit clan, who have intermarried with the mountain peoples, and who honor their customs, participate in their rituals, and keep their secrets.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K6_1}Karahan
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K6_1}Karahan lies in in the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. The villagers here buy horses from the wandering tribes, and raise some of their own, making this the source for many of the steeds ridden by the Khuzait armies.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K6_2}Nutyuk
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K6_2}Nutyuk sits in the plains of the upper Tiagys River, known by the Khuzaits as the Tayegh. The villagers here, mostly recently settled nomads, raise sheep like their ancestors.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.village_K6_3}Danara
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K6_3}Danara sits near the source of the headwaters of the Tiagys River in the foothills of the Kohi Rohini, the mountains of the dawn. Salt and sulfur springs flow out of fissures in the rock here, giving the waters of the river an acrid taste until, further down, they are diluted by other creeks and streams.

Settlement.name: {=Settlements.Settlement.name.castle_village_K7_2}Tismil
Settlement.text: {=Settlements.Settlement.text.village_K2_2}Tismil sits on the Ozu River, which drains the southern end of the Devseg plateau. The region is a center of horse-raising, as noyans seek to breed new larger warhorses that still retain the hardiness and adaptability of their ancestors' steppe ponies.

Settlement.name: {=8dDNWHR4}The Retreat
Settlement.text: {=E3rYg96K}This is the retirement retreat location.
